text: Bill McColl has 25+ years of experience as a senior producer and writer for TV, radio, and digital media leading teams of anchors, reporters, and editors in creating news broadcasts, covering some of the most notable news stories of the time. SOPA Images / Contributor / Getty Images The S&P 500 jumped above the 5,000 mark Friday as anticipated revisions to inflation data confirmed prices moved in the Federal Reserve's desired direction. The Nasdaq was also higher, but the Dow fell. Shares of Nvidia (NVDA) hit an all-time high following a report the chipmaker plans to launch a new unit to grab a share of the growing market for custom chips. FirstEnergy (FE) shares gained as the utility beat earnings estimates and announced a $26 billion capital investment plan. PayPal (PYPL) shares rebounded after plummeting yesterday following the electronic payments provider's warning about current quarter and full-year earnings as it undergoes a “significant transformation” to drive profitable growth. Expedia Group (EXPE) was the worst-performing stock in the S&P 500 after the online travel site’s gross bookings missed expectations, and CEO Peter Kern stepped down. Shares of Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) slumped as the video game maker missed quarterly earnings and warned about the current quarter on slowing sales of its NBA2K24 game and soft mobile ad revenue. PepsiCo (PEP) shares fell as the soft drink and snack maker’s revenue declined on lower volumes and disadvantageous currency rates. Oil futures advanced and gold prices declined. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose. The U.S. dollar lost ground to the euro and pound, but climbed versus the yen. The cryptocurrency rally continued, with Bitcoin trading above $47,000. TradingView
